images.caption: Figure 1:UFO3: Weaving the Digital Agent Galaxy.A single natural-language intent is decomposed into a dynamically evolved Constellation (DAG) executed across heterogeneous devices. Demo video available at:https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NGrVWGcJL8o.
Figure 2:Layered architecture ofUFO3.
Figure 3:Example of aTaskConstellationillustrating both sequential and parallel dependencies.
Figure 4:An overview of theConstellationAgent.
Figure 5:Lifecycle state transitions of theConstellationAgent.
Figure 6:The Constellation Orchestrator bridgesTaskConstellationand execution, enabling asynchronous, adaptive task orchestration across devices.
Figure 7:Illustration of asynchronous scheduling and concurrentTaskConstellationediting.
Figure 8:An example of the safe assignment locking and event synchronization workflow.
Figure 10:Agent registration flow: multi-source AgentProfile construction and registration.
Figure 12:The three-layer framework of a device agent.
Figure 13:The server-client architecture of a device agent.
Figure 15:Lifecycle state transitions of the LinuxAgent.
Figure 16:Overall architecture of the WindowsAgent built upon UFO2. Figure adapted from the original paper.
Figure 17:Snapshot of theUFO3WebUI. The interface integrates natural-language interaction,TaskConstellationvisualization, and device agent management in real time.
Figure 18:Example Markdown log generated byUFO3, showing agent actions, reasoning,TaskConstellationDAG (before and after edits).
Figure 19:Distribution ofNebulaBenchtasks. Left: proportion of tasks by difficulty. Right: number of devices involved per task.
Figure 20:Task and subtask success rates by difficulty level (left) and by query category (right) ofUFO3.
Figure 21:Comparison of the initial and final task (left) and dependency (right) counts in theTaskConstellationofUFO3.
Figure 22:Task timing and orchestration breakdown by difficulty.
Figure 23:Fault injection scenarios for robustness evaluation.UFO3â€™s adaptive behavior under (1) transient, (2) permanent, and (3) full-agent failures.

Figure 24:Case 1: Log collection and report generation.UFO3decomposes the high-level request into parallel log retrieval tasks on Linux agents and sequential report-generation tasks on Windows, demonstrating cross-device coordination and result aggregation.

Figure 25:Case 2: Distributed task execution from a centralized Excel sheet.UFO3interprets structured task descriptions from Excel, distributes them to Linux agents for execution, and writes concise summaries back into the corresponding cells.

Figure 26:Case 3: Resource-aware orchestration of distributed computation.UFO3dynamically inspects hardware and workload conditions on four Linux agents, assigns tasks based on available resources, and generates a human-readable summary report on Windows.
